It will take you to your homeland, Son, which you have never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui were behind them. Lily put her arm around Chen's shoulders. "The little old ship," Chen said. "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee did not want to let go of the telescope, and when he finally did, the telescope stopped working. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship was gone over the horizon, and Lily could only see seagulls flying around.

**THE WELL**
I had read that if you dig a deep enough hole, you could see the stars on a clear day. I convinced you to help me with my plan. You watched with wide eyes as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it on the wall, and then climbed in. I asked you to let me down. I didn’t think about how heavy the bucket was or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You held the handle, trying to help as I pushed the bucket off the side of the well. As soon as it was free, I fell down. You screamed and tried to stop it, but then you let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. At that moment, I didn’t realize I had achieved part of my plan. I saw strange lights, like stars, but it was only later that I connected these lights to the cartoon images I had seen when a character got hurt.
At first, I was confused, then scared, and finally angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what my mother would say. You called down to check if I was okay. I opened my mouth to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I couldn’t speak. I lay still, peeking at you through my eyelashes. You disappeared, calling for help. I waited a moment, then climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge, landing on the courtyard stones. I heard alarmed voices coming from the castle. I ran away to hide in the shadows by the moat bridge. 
My mother and father arrived with you and old Arthur. My mother was screaming, and my father was shouting for Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You stood back, looking pale and shocked. I was hidden in the shadows, feeling a strange excitement. Then I noticed the drops of water I had left from the well to where I stood. I looked in horror at the dark spots on the dry stones. At my feet, the water had formed a small pool. I looked back into the courtyard, where my father was shining a flashlight down into the well. The drops sparkled in the sunlight, and I couldn’t believe no one had seen them. My mother was now screaming loudly, a sound I had never heard before. It shook me. What should I do? I had gotten back at you, but things had become more serious than I expected. What started as a fun prank was now a situation that could lead to serious trouble for me.
I regretted not thinking this through. In just a few minutes, my clever plan had turned into a disaster. Suddenly, I had an idea, like a lifeline to a drowning person. I gathered my courage and left my hiding place, staggering out and blinking. I called out softly, then yelled louder when no one heard me. I stumbled a bit further and then fell dramatically on the stones. Sitting up, with my mother comforting me, I sighed and said, “Oh dear,” smiling bravely. I claimed that I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat and crawled through it until I got out.
I thought I was almost getting away with it until my father appeared in front of me. He asked me to repeat my story. I hesitated. His eyes narrowed, and I realized I was only making things worse. I said the secret passage had collapsed after me, so there was no point in looking for it. I insisted the well was dangerous and that I had barely escaped with my life. Looking into my father’s eyes felt like looking into a dark tunnel with no light at the end. It seemed like he was seeing me for the first time, and I felt like I was looking into a future where I would understand how the world works, and how foolish my lies were.
My words got stuck in my throat. “Don’t be ridiculous, boy,” he said, with more contempt than I thought possible. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked down at me, looking regretful and troubled. He seemed to want to shake his head, not because I had a scary adventure and my father didn’t believe me, but because he could see through my lie. He worried about what this meant for my character and future. His pity felt like a harsh judgment, even worse than my father’s, and it affected me deeply.

**REMOVAL DAY**
Now that her children are grown, Susan, who is a widow, must leave her family home. The van had the words 'Removers of Distinction' on it, and indeed, everything that made the house special was being taken away. Fred, the removal man, was carefully wrapping fragile items in newspaper and packing them into boxes, while his helpers were not as gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-story house that looked over a small harbor. The memories of her children growing up there felt present in the air, like dust.
When they first bought the house, her son Robert, who was five at the time, had asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" It was easy to miss the little boy he used to be, especially now that he was an adult helping her move. He was making sure she didn’t mention the piano. Francesca, her daughter, was also helping, being bossy and determined to take care of the Steinway piano.
Fred noticed Susan was not crying. He said, "That's something." When Susan asked if people usually cry, Fred replied, "You'd be surprised. They seem happy while packing, but then they cry in an empty room. They feel sad when they see everything taken apart." Susan could understand that feeling. She would have warned the movers about the piano, but Robert insisted it was their job to notice.
The piano was the last item to be moved. Susan sat on the bottom stair, remembering the day they moved in. It felt like that day was playing in reverse. The piano had been brought in first and got stuck on the stairs. The movers struggled for nearly two hours to get it up. Little Robert watched in amazement while Francesca cried, "We can't live in a house without a piano!" They had to find a way to get it inside, and her late husband, Peter, had solved the problem. They left the piano outside while they moved in the other furniture. The next day, a builder took out the first-floor window, and a crane was borrowed to lift the piano through the window. The children were overjoyed to see it come in. However, it cost a lot, and they had to wait months to have it tuned.
Peter had said, "That's there forever." But forever is a long time. The children were too busy to visit often, and Susan found it harder to move around the house. She thought about the stairs and remembered the banister rails were not perfectly fixed. She should have warned the movers, but it was too late now. 
Fred asked her if she was okay. "Just the piano left now, and then we’ll be done," he said. Susan moved away from the stairs, feeling anxious. Robert and Francesca appeared to watch. Fred casually asked, "No tears then?" Susan felt close to crying. It was strange how moving things made them feel important. Items that seemed unimportant before now felt full of emotion, and she thought she might cry.
Just then, the piano appeared at the top of the stairs, with Fred leading and another mover behind. It tipped slightly. "Easy does it!" Fred called out, and they carefully brought it down the stairs and out the front door, placing it behind the van. Robert was the first to laugh, and soon they were all laughing, relieved that it was over. They leaned against each other, gasping for breath and laughing more. Fred asked, "What's the joke?" but his question only made them laugh harder. As they walked down the path for the last time, the only tears Susan shed were tears of laughter.

**Online Literary Criticism for Everyone: Is DIY Literary Criticism Just Fun?**
From the beginning, one of the main ideas of the Internet was to allow open access. In theory, anyone could publish their thoughts or share music online. However, in the early days, some technical skills were needed. Still, there was one area that became truly available to everyone: literary criticism. 
By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could try writing book reviews. Amazon allowed anyone to share their opinions about books and give them up to five stars. This seemed like a great idea because it meant that readers could see what others thought about a book, not just the publisher's description or professional critics' opinions. Other online bookstores also offered similar features, but Amazon was the largest, with over 80% of the online market. This meant it had the most customers and the most reviews, but it also faced some problems.
Many reviews were submitted every day, and Amazon did not say how many. It was impossible to check all of them. Instead, a team of editors looked for reviews that followed the company's rules. For example, one-word reviews or personal attacks on authors were not allowed. Reviews that gave away the ending or included bad language were also removed. However, since reviewers could remain anonymous, it was easy for some to misbehave. For instance, authors could write positive reviews for their own books. 
One author, Lev Grossman, was upset by the bad reviews of his first novel. To balance things out, he wrote some positive reviews under a fake name. His trick worked until he wrote an article about it, and then Amazon removed the fake reviews. Authors could also comment on their own books by clicking a link that said, "I am the Author, and I wish to comment on my book." Most authors used this to encourage readers to buy and enjoy their books. Some even shared their email addresses for direct communication. However, Amazon did not always check if these comments were really from the authors, except for well-known writers.
The real drama began with reader reviews. When James McElroy's book, *We've Got Spirit*, was published, it received good reviews from the press. However, many people mentioned in the book felt hurt and used Amazon to express their anger. Many negative reviews appeared but were quickly removed. Despite this, Amazon saw the large number of reviews as good for business. 
Amazon wanted reviews to be a place to discuss books, not just a chat room. They paid special attention to bestselling books to ensure all reviews followed the rules. This meant that silly reviews were more likely to appear on pages for less popular books. For example, a classic children's book called *The Story about Ping* inspired some humorous reviews because "ping" is also a term used in technology. One long review compared the book's story to Internet architecture, saying it provided a good overview of networking concepts. However, such silliness was rare. 
Most readers took their reviews seriously, and overall, the reviews gave a good idea of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books made it hard to have real feelings about them. This is why the opening up of literary criticism to everyone is seen as a positive change.

**Art in Modern Times**
In recent years, especially over the last two hundred years, we often think that every artist must go against the art of their time. Art is often praised for being unique, revolutionary, or even shocking. We feel proud to admire artists whose work was not appreciated in the past. However, when it comes to contemporary art, we sometimes hesitate and say that an artist has gone too far, or that their work is no longer art. The media often expresses these feelings for us, and we tend to agree because we expect art to always be new and different. This expectation makes us overlook the old themes and methods that are still present in today’s art. We want artists to be different from us, with special talents that break the rules. In the past, people commissioned artists for specific purposes, and art was part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to work on their own and can become frustrated if they try to connect with us.
**Picture This**
I will describe a situation and then ask an important question about it. An artist picks a piece of text from an art book that talks about the variety of pictures. The text asks, "What are they all about?" and then says, "There is no end to the different kinds of pictures." This language seems childish, but let’s continue. The artist then asks someone to prepare a canvas for him and to take it to a sign painter. He instructs the sign painter to write the chosen text on the canvas in simple black letters without any decoration. The sign painter does this. My important question is: is the final product a painting?
**Underground Encounters**
At the Mercury Gallery in London, there is an unspoken rule for painters: once you find a successful style, you should stick to it. Collectors expect artists to keep producing similar work, and if they try something new, it can upset people. I’m not sure why this is the case. Gallery owners prefer safe choices, and perhaps art buyers feel more comfortable with familiar styles. However, some artists break this rule and succeed, like Picasso and Hockney. Eric Rimmington is another artist who is trying something different. His new exhibition changes from the still lifes he is known for to paintings of the London Underground. Rimmington finds the railway fascinating. He started with drawings of Kings Cross Station in the 1980s and then decided to explore what happens underground. His exhibition, "Underground Encounters," features 40 paintings and drawings that capture the unique charm of this hidden world.
**Extract from a Novel**
I have come to this island with a few books. I use the word "escape" because the villagers joke that only a sick person would choose such a remote place to live. I have come here to heal myself. Besides an old woman from the village who comes daily to clean, I am alone. I feel neither happy nor sad; I am like a feather floating in memories. I mentioned the uselessness of art but did not speak about its comforts. The comfort of my work lies in the fact that in the quiet moments of a painter or writer, reality can be changed and shown in a new way. Our everyday actions often hide the deeper meaning of life. For artists, art allows us to deal with the pain and struggles of daily life, not to escape from it, but to fulfill our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why would we hurt each other?

**Family Business**
"Look, this isn't good!" said my Dad. We were in the car on our way back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice beside him, had just picked me up from the fancy girls' school I attended. He had also just been to Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for the best results in my end-of-school exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were heading home for the holidays.
"What isn't?" I asked, although I had a feeling I knew what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. Normally, he talked a lot. "You can't fool me. Now that you have all those certificates, you'll do what you want," he said. "I heard you might get a scholarship to Oxford." 
"So?" I replied, trying to act tough. "Isn't that useful?" 
"I also heard," he continued, and I knew a serious conversation was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My father knew a lot about lawyers and the law. 
"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else!" 
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality. You can quickly understand a lot of information, you are good at speaking, and you enjoy performing." 
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV." 
"Regardless," he said, gathering himself, "I feel like your heart isn't in the family business anymore. You will go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us." 
The problem was that, like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by my father's expectations. I saw many career options for myself and wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I still found him intimidating. 
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly. 
"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," my father said, who often seemed to be right about these things. "It's a shame because you have the talent - the intelligence, the courage, the vision." 
"There's still Maurice," I said, feeling down. My father scoffed. We both knew Maurice didn't like the business. 
"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a consultant." My mother had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger than me, and since he was motherless, I took care of him. It wasn't hard; I loved him. 
Because the business was successful, we lived comfortably - in a big house in London, attended nice schools, wore good clothes, and enjoyed parties, theaters, and operas. My father knew many interesting people - politicians, actors, and businessmen - and our home was always lively.
"I have an idea," my father said. "You can help us during the holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some pocket money and help me." 
"Okay," I said, relieved to avoid making immediate choices, especially since my father would be upset if I disagreed. This was how he controlled us. 
So, it happened. In my last term at school and during university breaks, I helped out, never more than twice a year and always with easier tasks. I became one of the top students, had a small house, a nice car, designer clothes, and a black dress from Paris that I planned to wear for my final exams. 
In my last term, my father came to visit me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left until my exams. My tutor said I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I focused and organized my thoughts, he might be right. I felt ready and confident. 
But then my father told me that he needed me to do one last important task for the family business, the biggest one they had ever attempted, and he promised it would be worth my time. 
"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important for me to do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now." 
I could tell my father didn't understand the pressure I was under (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him), and he would see my refusal as a betrayal. As he explained the task, I realized how determined he was, how clearly he approached his work, and how much energy and control he had. In his way, he was brilliant, and I admired that in him. It made my own plans seem less important. 
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with Lois. It was clear that a house they could only afford by being very careful with money was not worth having at all. However, at the time, it seemed like a good and desirable decision. Simon had been successful in his work, and cases were coming in regularly. Lois had returned to her job at the advertising agency just two months after giving birth to their twins and received a raise that brought her salary to thirty-five thousand. She strongly wanted to move, and Simon did not resist her arguments, which seemed convincing at the time: their flat was not suitable for a family, they needed more space, a garden, and a separate room for an au pair. They could have found these things in a less expensive area of London, but Lois wanted more than just extra space. She felt that living in Mornington Mansions was not good enough for a rising barrister and a successful businesswoman. Even saying the name of their old flat made her feel like it lowered her status.
Lois decided that one of them should save money by using public transport. Since her office was on the other side of London, Simon had to be the one to travel by tube. The crowded journey made him feel resentful and unhappy, and he often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he had stayed as a boy. He remembered the smell of dinner and how his grandmother took care of his grandfather after a long day at work. She was a supportive wife, always involved in legal causes and happy with her life. But that world was gone. Lois had made it clear before they married that her career was just as important as his. This was a modern marriage, and they both needed their jobs. Their lifestyle depended on both of their salaries. 
Now, what they had worked hard for was at risk because of Venetia, who had come to their office in a bad mood. Something had upset her, and she confronted Simon with intense anger. He blamed himself for not leaving his room earlier, thinking that if he had, the argument might not have happened. He remembered every word of her accusations. She said, "I defended Brian Cartwright today. He told me that when you were his lawyer four years ago, you knew he bribed three jurors. You did nothing. Is that true?" Simon replied, "He's lying. It isn't true." She continued, "He also said he gave shares in his company to your fiancée before the trial. Is that true?" Again, Simon denied it, but his response felt unconvincing even to him. He felt guilty and ashamed, remembering the fear of punishment from his school days. When he looked into her eyes, he saw her disbelief.
He wished he had said, "Cartwright told me after the trial, but I didn't believe him. I still don't believe him. He will say anything to make himself look important." Instead, he had told a more dangerous lie, and she knew it was a lie. But why was she so angry? What did his past actions have to do with her? Why was Venetia acting as if she was the judge of his professional life? Was her own behavior always perfect? Did she have the right to ruin his career? He was not sure what she could do, but if this rumor spread, it could destroy him.

I chose this place to live because I thought I would be anonymous among people who didn’t care about the worn-out rented houses and messy gardens. However, I was wrong. The shopkeepers, who are living their real lives, soon start to recognize me. The beautiful roses from my neighbor’s garden remind me that gardens can be loved. Usually, I stay inside to forget about the summer outside, but tonight I am watching the swifts flying between the trees and roofs. I have trimmed some herbs to make space for a chair, and my arms are stinging from scratches. It is a small London garden where plants must grow tall or spread out to survive.
“Been doing some clearing, I see,” says my upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leaning out of her window. She is a writer with several unpublished works, and I sometimes help her with them as an English teacher. I have her latest manuscript with me. “How’s the work going, Jaz?” I ask. “Honestly, in no other job do people ask you about your work so many times a day,” she replies. Then she says, “I have something to drink in the fridge. I’ll bring it down.” I don’t want Jaz in the garden, and I realize it looks messy. She knocks on my door. “So, you’re on holiday now, lucky you,” she says, sitting in the chair while I drop a cushion onto what used to be a small lawn. “Cheers,” she says, acting young. “I should’ve gone into teaching – writers don’t have holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can’t, teach.” And then there are those who can do neither.
“So, what are your plans for the holidays?” she asks. I feel overwhelmed by the empty days ahead. “Actually, I’m going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed my cats?” I ask. My heart races as I speak. “Of course,” Jaz replies, knowing she will be around. “Where will you stay? A nice bed and breakfast?” “No, I’ll stay with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We’ve known each other since we were eight.” This isn’t true, but I often deal with fiction. “Going back to your roots. What do you think of my manuscript?” Jaz asks about her story, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I haven’t read much of. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other houses and returning her manuscripts in silly bags.
I decide to be honest for once. “Let me give you a little tip,” I say. “What?” she asks, surprised. “Try writing about nice people for a change, people who want to be good: a little less self-centeredness, a bit more fiction…” “Teachers!” Jaz replies, acting like a rebellious student. “I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,” I say. My words sound a bit old-fashioned. “Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.” Oh, I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes, reading on the tube. When we finally go inside, my calm kitchen gives me a moment of comfort, but suddenly I remember my old geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now, winking at us and saying, “I’ve had my moments.” We nearly died laughing.

**Heritage**
Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to their past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and hearing stories about their lives. However, there is also a need to learn about our wider past to help us understand our future, both as individuals and as a nation. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity; knowing about the past helps us feel secure about the future. Just as we inherit our genes, we also inherit a culture that has been passed down through generations. There may be parts of our national heritage that we do not like, but it is still a part of who we are, and it can be comforting to feel connected to something larger. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being. It influences our customs and material culture. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories and legends from our ancestors. However, in modern society, many of these oral traditions have been lost. Now, we often look to places and buildings to understand our past. It is very important to preserve these connections as a way to honor our ancestors' identities.
**The Fens**
Some time ago, I started writing a novel called *Waterland*, where the landscape of a region in England called the Fens became very important. After the book was published, people asked me why I, a Londoner with no personal connection to the Fens, chose to write about this area. The simple answer is that I found the Fens interesting because they seemed quiet and empty, providing a blank space for my story. However, I learned that the Fens are not truly flat or empty. They are uniquely English but also strangely different. It is surprising that in the middle of England, there is a place that many English people find unfamiliar, especially since many other unique areas of Britain have become part of the national culture. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated and wild, seemingly simple yet deeply mysterious. While writing my novel, I did not explore the Fens extensively; I have not yet visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I prefer to create imagined worlds rather than seek strict facts. However, trying to imagine the Fens has its own logic, as they are not just a landscape but also a way of thinking.
**Museums**
Museums need to make their collections easy to access. In the past, this meant simply putting items in display cases with long descriptions that were hard for most people to understand. Today, accessibility should mean more than that. Displays can be engaging and use creative techniques to attract visitors and evoke emotions. However, museums should be about more than just displays; they should reach out to the widest community possible. For example, some museums provide loan boxes of objects for teachers, and recently, they have started offering similar materials for elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on real objects and specimens, not replicas. They exist to provide a genuine experience with history. They show items that were used and had meaning at some point in time. This is their strength and what sets them apart from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and CDs. Museums that meet this challenge and create exciting and accessible displays will find that their competitors in "virtual history" can actually help them by increasing interest in real historical experiences.
**Architecture and Environment**
The desire to preserve things is not new, but changes in our towns happen quickly and on a large scale, affecting many of us. This can make some people very focused on preservation and encourage others to think more about the nature of our towns today and their future. It can be argued that people who have lived through significant events, like world wars, are more likely to want to preserve things because stability becomes important to them. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners should consider it. Change is not necessarily bad if we learn how to manage it. Changes in our towns reflect social changes, such as population growth, welfare, and our needs.

Einstein**
If you stop someone in the street and ask them to name a scientist, they will likely say Albert Einstein. His image is often used to sell products that seem smart, like computers and encyclopedias. Most people know little about what Einstein actually did, except that he created some complex theories called 'relativity', which are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions that don’t match everyday experiences. 
Einstein was part of a major change in scientific thinking, which started the development of modern science in the twentieth century. Physicists and mathematicians were trying to find a new, clearer way to describe the universe by studying how matter and natural forces interact. Einstein made important contributions by rethinking the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, scientists followed Isaac Newton's idea that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein changed this idea, saying that time and space are not fixed but relative.
**Young Readers**
When we were children, Lydia and I did not trust any book that won awards because we thought they would be boring. Our mother often criticized us for this attitude, while our father would give us small coins as rewards to encourage us to read better books. He would also include some good books in our Christmas and birthday gifts, marked with a note saying, 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we thought most of his choices were 'boys' books', he did introduce us to some shorter works of good fiction and, once, to a famous collection of poetry.
**Language**
Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851, 'The origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous.' This secret has led to many strange ideas. For example, Charles Caller suggested in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they felt danger. This sound is sad. The early human who traveled through dangerous lands made desperate noises, and some words have kept a trace of this, like 'malaria' meaning "fever" and the Latin word 'mors' meaning "death". 
Many people avoided discussing the origin of language, thinking it was a topic for odd theories. However, recently, the study of how language began and evolved has become very important. Language likely started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, speech was mainly used for friendly communication and was important in struggles for power. Sharing information was probably not the main purpose of language, which goes against the ideas of philosopher John Locke, who described language as a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

Writing Reviews**
Frank Kermode looks at how to write reviews from the perspective of someone who does it. Most reviews are written quickly and do not last long. There are strict deadlines and limits on how long they can be. Once published, they are only read for a short time—usually a day, a week, or at most a month. Because of this, many people think that writing reviews is not very important. They believe that writers only do it for money or because they need a break from writing longer, more serious works.
However, writing reviews is a skilled job. It is different to write a short review of six or eight hundred words for a newspaper than to write a longer review of six or eight thousand words for an international journal. A review in a weekly magazine, which is about fifteen hundred words, has challenges from both short and long formats. 
Reviewers must think about their audience. Some readers may just skim the review, while others may want a detailed analysis. A good reviewer needs to know a lot about different topics and must write in a way that is clear and enjoyable for intelligent readers. This means that most reviewers also write other types of work.
The American novelist John Updike, who does not think highly of criticism, still enjoys writing reviews between his novel projects. He collects all his reviews, no matter how short, into books with modest titles. Some might think that less famous writers should accept that their reviews will not last, but it is understandable if they want their work to be remembered, especially if they feel their best writing is in those reviews.
I feel this way about my own writing. My main work has been in academia, and my serious books are academic in nature, which is what professors are expected to write. However, in the English-speaking world, there is no strict separation between reviewing and literary study, so it is common for the same people to do both. 
In the past, some academics criticized professors who wrote reviews for showing off or wasting time. But now, it is less common for non-professors to complain that professors are taking opportunities away from them. This is partly because there are many more reviews being written today, so almost anyone can write one, and also because the pay for writing reviews is often very low.
I believe that this situation is good for both readers and professors. Readers can trust that reviewers know what they are talking about, and professors benefit because writing reviews helps them stay connected to the public. It also reminds them that they need to communicate clearly with non-professors. While they may use complex language when talking to each other, they should make sure to be understandable when writing for a wider audience.
In conclusion, despite its importance, reviewing is usually a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also successful in another area of writing.

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and, as he stepped into the dark hallway, he felt a brief sense of ownership. Even after three years, this feeling sometimes surprised him when he returned home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home excited and curious, wondering what had happened in his absence. The flat felt like a welcoming place, a space where he could focus without distractions. 
He thought he should worry about things like intruders or broken pipes, but his flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either looking tidy or a bit messy, depending on how he had left it. Over time, he began to see it as an extension of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings spilled out. He grew frustrated with its inability to change. There were always a few letters piled up by the door and the answering machine blinking with messages when he got back. He was thankful that his windows were intact and that nothing had been stolen, but he often wondered what the flat would look like if something bad happened.
From his dull office on the third floor, Ralph looked forward to his quiet evenings at home. After leaving the busy office, he felt a bit more like himself on the bus ride home. However, he often found that he didn’t want to be alone, even though he thought he did. While sitting at his desk, he longed for solitude and time to himself, but once he escaped, he felt empty. This emptiness made him think that the work he did, which he didn’t enjoy, was changing him and pulling him away from who he really was.
He would often read or listen to music at night, but he started to question why he did these things. His thoughts became unclear, and he struggled to connect his feelings and ideas. He remembered a time when he felt more in control of his life. He had wanted to improve himself but found that he only wanted to get by. He applied for jobs that his friends talked about, following them as they moved forward, unable to see that he could find a job that would also make him happy.
He went to one job interview with gratitude and didn’t think to question the job itself, which was a vague editorial position at a local free newspaper. After a pleasant conversation with Neil, his potential boss, he didn’t consider what working there would mean for his future. Neil offered him the job right away, saying he was the only graduate who had applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**How to Be Presentation Perfect**
I am not good at making presentations, but as the managing director, I often have to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and my confidence? You are not alone. Making a presentation requires different skills than running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you are saying. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm during your presentation. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas beforehand and ask colleagues to help you think of difficult questions your audience might ask. You should also create a positive atmosphere from the beginning. Start with something everyone can relate to and gradually lead to the conclusion you want to reach.

Some activities cannot be rushed; they take the time they need. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient with making mayonnaise and add the oil too quickly, it will not turn out right. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot will just get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some tasks are done very quickly, while others take seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some things can be done faster, like solving crossword puzzles or doing math in your head. But other things cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they may fail, just like the mayonnaise or the fishing line.
The idea of "Think fast; we need results" can sometimes be unhelpful, just like trying to get a good night's sleep in a short time. We learn and think in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds. There are three main speeds of thinking. 
The first speed is faster than thought. Some situations need an immediate reaction. For example, when my motorbike skidded on a wet road, my body reacted quickly to keep me safe, and only later did I think about what happened. This quick reaction can be called our "wits." 
The second speed is thought itself. This involves reasoning, weighing options, and solving problems. For example, a mechanic figuring out why a car won’t start, a scientist studying an experiment, or a student working on an assignment are all using this type of intelligence, which we often call "intellect." People who are good at solving these problems are seen as "bright" or "clever."
The third speed is slower and less focused. It is more relaxed and dreamy. In this mode, we think about things without a clear purpose. For example, when we are sitting by the sea, listening to the waves, or just waking up, we are in a different mental state than when we are planning a meal or writing a letter. This slower way of thinking is just as important as the faster ones. 
Taking time to think slowly is necessary, especially when life gets busy. We need this "tortoise mind" just as much as the "hare brain." Some everyday problems are better solved with a slow mind. Some complex issues can only be understood with a relaxed attitude. Recent studies show that slower thinking is good for understanding complicated situations. 
Deliberate thinking works well for clear problems. For example, deciding where to go on holiday is usually straightforward. But when we are unsure about what to consider or when the issue is complicated, we need to use our slow thinking. If we are trying to manage a difficult group of people at work or deciding whether to change careers, it may be better to sit and think rather than rush for answers. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and wisdom. 
Poets and philosophers have long understood the limits of fast thinking and have encouraged slower ways of knowing. Recently, scientists have started to study these slower ways of thinking. The field of cognitive science is showing that our unconscious mind can do many interesting and important tasks if given enough time. It can recognize patterns that our conscious mind might miss, understand complex situations, and solve difficult problems better than quick thinking can.

Surviving in a Foreign Land**

**Elliot**
When I first met Elliot, I was just a young author, and he did not pay much attention to me. He remembered faces, though, and when I saw him, he would shake my hand politely but did not seem interested in getting to know me better. If I saw him at the opera with someone important, he would often not notice me. However, when I became successful as a playwright, I noticed that Elliot started to look at me differently. One day, he sent me a note asking me to lunch, and I thought he was trying to get to know me. After that, as my success brought me many new friends, I began to see him more often.
**Alfred Hitchcock**
The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said that he did not care about the story of his films or the acting, but he did care about the visuals and the sound. For Hitchcock, it was not a message or a great performance that moved the audience; he believed that people react to the film itself, no matter their background. So, if a film is made well in terms of its emotional effect, the audience in Japan should react the same way as the audience in India. Hitchcock was very clear and logical about his work. He was a man of reason and a talented craftsman who liked to hear the audience scream. He did not focus on speculation or deep ideas, and he did not explore his characters in a complicated way. He concentrated on film itself and the precise beauty of what a film can do to an audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**
Many things have changed in astronomy over the last fifty years. Until about thirty years ago, there were not many charts and catalogues available. Telescopes were limited, and there were few books on practical astronomy. Today, there are many types of telescopes and equipment that cover almost everything needed. Electronic calculators and computers have changed how we create almanacs and charts, making it easier to analyze observations and publish results. This could be seen as the golden age of amateur astronomy. However, some things have been lost as well. Now, you may have to travel 80 km to find a dark sky, which was easier to find in cities 50 years ago. Daytime skies are often filled with trails from airplanes, which can last for hours and create clouds, making it hard to observe the sun and stars at night.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, people have too many choices. There are too many things to do and too many options available. In our modern economy, the desire for new products and services has become an addiction, and technology speeds up this change. New products come out quickly, and just as one is released, another is on the way. This can be overwhelming and tiring, leading to a feeling of disconnection from life. While choice is important in our economy, having too many choices can cause stress, take up time, and make life more complicated. There are more basic brands of detergent and breakfast cereals than we could ever need, along with countless software updates and plans to choose from.

Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This is a family tradition started by my grandmother, and it has become very important to us. Othello and Lake Vostok**

**Lake Vostok**  
In the middle of Antarctica, there is nothing alive. On the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But in the vast white area in the center, life does not exist—except for a large hidden body of freshwater called Lake Vostok, which is under nearly 4 kilometers of ice, right below the coldest place on Earth. The water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its mysterious depths and find out what strange organisms might be there. Geologists and glaciologists are also interested. For two years, researchers around the world have been planning ways to uncover the secrets of the lake, and if they succeed, we will see many discoveries about Lake Vostok in the next few years.
**Scientists**  
Last week, I heard something interesting on the radio. A group of scientists is discussing what motivates them to be scientists. The phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know that the quest for knowledge drives us, the desire to understand everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists want to know why we have this desire for knowledge and why science cannot explain this motivation. I believe it is more important to focus on whether what scientists do is right, rather than getting stuck in debates about the purpose of science. **Food**

No one would want to have takeout for a wedding or anniversary party, and most people wouldn’t discuss business over canned soup.
**In the Elevator**  
This morning, Alistair tried to clean up his office, but there were still papers everywhere. Tax forms were overflowing from drawers and boxes, waiting for a day when he would organize them. He also had a lot of paperwork from owning an apartment building. Many books and journals were close to new bookshelves. **Joanna's Lessons**
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. So, why has she decided to write books for young children learning the piano? Even someone who cannot hear music well would be impressed by her performances. Watching her play the piano, moving quickly and playing many notes, shows how talented she is. However, at a recent concert for kids, one small boy surprised her. After watching her play different styles of music, he asked, "Can you play Match of the Day?" This request made Joanna laugh. She realized that, to him, she was not a real pianist until she played that song. Of course, she played it and noted the experience for her next children's concert.
Joanna is unique among top concert pianists because she cares about how young children learn to play. She has just published her own beginner piano book for children called *Joanna MacGregor's Piano World*. She managed to write this book despite her busy schedule. This summer, she is performing at many festivals and working with young composers and artists. She also runs her own recording label, Sound Circus, and loves to collaborate with other artists.
So, why did she take on the extra work of writing a book? "People who know me are surprised," she says. "But I believe the first lessons are very important. Many music teachers focus only on talented children, but most people enjoy music in a more everyday way. I find that much more interesting!"
Joanna's experience helps her write these books. From ages 18 to 25, before she became a concert pianist, she taught many beginners. She also grew up in a home where her mother taught piano, and many children came to learn. "I played around on the piano while other kids of all backgrounds wanted to play different types of music. I didn't focus on only the talented ones. I believe everyone should have the chance to learn music."
Just like everyone should learn to swim or speak a little French, Joanna thinks everyone should try to learn the piano. Some children learn quickly, while others take their time and sometimes give up. This can happen at any stage. Some kids find the beginning too hard, while others feel pressure to be like the talented children they see on TV. 
"I worry that some people use music, like sports, to push their children to achieve things instead of just enjoying it. Children often quit because they feel they cannot meet their parents' expectations."
When asked if she thinks other piano books are not good enough, Joanna is careful with her words. "I don't want to criticize other teachers or their books," she says. She believes her colorful and engaging books are not the only ones that make learning fun. To help young beginners, she includes stories in her books and CDs. The challenge is to make learning interesting. From the first lesson, there are fun accompaniments for teachers or parents to play along with the child. For kids whose parents cannot play, the accompaniments are on the CDs.
Joanna insists that learning should be fun. "You need to let them improvise and encourage them to play all over the keyboard." As children progress, they need to learn to read music instead of just playing by ear. Joanna understands this challenge because she relied on her ear when she was young. However, she believes that practice is the most important part of learning.
How can children be encouraged to play a piece more than once? Joanna admits she did not practice much until she attended the Royal Academy of Music, where she had to practice a lot to learn difficult pieces. Now, she loves practicing. She spends about eight hours a day practicing, which she says is more important than performing. "I understand how hard it can be for some people. We need to talk about it more."
Joanna shares some tips for practice: "Whether you practice for twenty minutes or five hours, decide what you want to achieve first. Also, reward yourself by playing the whole piece, even if you make mistakes. And mix difficult pieces with easier ones."

Human culture has always had strong feelings about birds. But what does this say about us? Paul Evans reports.
In a greenhouse, a little brown bird called a wren is bumping against the glass. Some people see the wren as a sign of something important, while others think it is just a bird that is lost. Both ideas could be true. 
Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed that the direction in which wrens flew could tell them about their luck. Today, images of wrens can be found in many British homes. Even if old beliefs about wrens are not as strong now, people still care about them. A place without wrens feels sad. 
This connection to birds comes from a time when people relied more on nature for survival. They developed a way to understand the importance of different creatures. However, beliefs about birds can change over time. 
For example, the red kite was once seen as a valuable bird in London, where it would take bread from children. But later, people began to see it as a pest, and it almost disappeared from many areas. Now, red kites are protected again and are symbols of conservation in Britain.
Our relationship with birds goes back to the beginning of human history. Early humans watched birds closely because they could warn them about danger, bad weather, and food sources. Birds also connected them to their dreams. 
Birds are important to us because they represent flight, song, and freedom. Our interest in birds reflects our own identity and connection to nature. Some people think our feelings about birds are outdated, but they are still a part of who we are. Losing this connection would be difficult.
Recently, birds have become important indicators of environmental change. In Britain, 30 bird species are now endangered. This is sad not only because we are losing these birds but also because we are losing part of our culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing represent love and magic in literature. The loss of these birds is felt deeply by those who appreciate poetry and stories.
However, the loss of other birds that are not mentioned in literature is often ignored. Folklore, which includes stories and legends about birds, is very important. These stories create a strong connection to birds that scientific terms cannot match. They help us feel emotions that are often hidden in our busy lives.
Whether we watch birds on TV or in our backyards, the joy we feel cannot be fully explained by science. Birds engage us in ways that are hard to understand. The wren in the greenhouse connects our present with a rich history, holding onto its song and moving into the future—a mystery that keeps us curious.

**Maps**
The purpose of a map is to show the relationships between different points and features on the earth's surface. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In the past, distance was often described in terms of time, such as "a few hours' walk" or "a day's journey by river." This way of measuring distance was more about how easy it was to travel through the land than about the actual distance. Direction was also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far away is it?" Therefore, having an accurate direction was not always necessary. Because of this, written directions were often used alongside maps. Even today, some maps, like those showing train routes, do not always show true directions.
In early maps, important landmarks were marked with signs that varied in size to show their significance. The way maps were made depended on their purpose and location, so it is important to understand the specific style used in early maps. The history of map-making, or cartography, is mainly about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and expanding the information included on maps. To achieve this, cartographers have used knowledge from other sciences. For example, instead of finding direction by looking at shadows or stars, they began using the magnetic compass and developed tools to measure angles accurately.
As knowledge of the world grew through exploration, attempts to create maps of known areas increased. Astronomers found that the earth is not a perfect sphere but is slightly flattened at the poles, which led to better mapping techniques. Over time, the needs of map users changed. Travelers and merchants were no longer the only ones using maps. Soldiers, especially after the invention of artillery, needed accurate maps to understand the land's features. This led to the creation of contour maps. Other users, like archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers, also had specific needs for maps.
Today, cartographers create maps that show various types of information, such as geological layers, climate zones, and land use. The growing recognition of the importance of maps in many scientific fields has led to a modern revival of cartography. However, it is important to note that the development of maps has not always been steady. There have been times of slow progress, interrupted by periods of rapid change, where old ideas coexisted with new ones. Cartographers have often understood the need for progress but had to wait for better tools to implement their ideas. Since it is easier to copy old maps, many map publishers have been slow to accept new ideas.
Therefore, maps should not be taken at face value as proof of current knowledge and techniques. The many maps we have today are the result of significant human effort and thought. They provide a valuable record for studying human history, which makes the study of historical cartography both interesting and educational.

I was taken into a young man's living room, which was a calm and cultured space surrounded by a messy group of rooms where the less ambitious family members lived. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class. This room had the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player I had encountered, and surprising evidence that a teenager had spent money on nice wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had received a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting, during which he wanted to become England's version of the famous composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as crazy; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. However, my dreams were not as important to me as Andrew's were to him. If I had failed, my dreams might have felt more serious. So, when Andrew suggested that I try to become a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I was open to it. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting him, he played me three of his own tunes, and I could tell he was very talented. As he confidently played songs from the many shows he had created at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' collection. He needed a new lyricist for his work. I didn’t have much to impress him with, except for praising his music and showing him a seven-inch single of a song I had written with an unknown pop group that had not done well. We said goodbye, promising to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I thought I had met someone with rare talent and determination, and I would be foolish to miss the chance to work with someone who was likely to succeed in musical theatre soon. Even if we didn’t become top composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later in the summer. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and would need new songs.
The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to be a lawyer, the excitement I had felt about a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber had faded a bit. I would still look at small ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a singer and write a few more simple songs that wouldn’t show my voice’s limitations. But it was likely that I would finish my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would probably have outgrown pop music, as my father had predicted I would by twenty-one. This worried me—if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But for now, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to go to a musical with him and write lyrics that were more like those of musical writers than pop stars. Andrew was an interesting person who talked about good food and Victorian architecture and supported the Leyton Orient football team. I wasn’t sure about the musical idea he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965, I was rarely sure about anything. His talent was clear, and he claimed to have many important contacts. I soon found myself back in his living room. The idea was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a 19th-century philanthropist who started the orphanages that carry his name. His story was important, but it didn’t really inspire me. The hero seemed too perfect in Andrew's version, and the idea felt unoriginal, too similar to Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. However, Andrew's strong belief in his music's brilliance was contagious and not completely unjustified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who would later be my agent for over twenty-five years, often said, if there is a demand for one hamburger place on the block, there is room for two. We could be the second hamburger place. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially for the funny songs. Andrew explained the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the titles, most of which had likely been thought up by his school friend who had already tried. I even skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first set of theatrical lyrics. I didn’t know it then, but I had changed my career.

**Language**  
You and I are part of a species that has a special ability: we can influence each other's thoughts with great accuracy. Language is so important to human life that it is hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will likely start talking to each other. When there is no one to talk to, people often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct.' This means that people know how to speak in a way similar to how spiders know how to spin webs. Web-spinning was not created by a brilliant spider, and it does not require special education or skills in building.
**Climate and Weather**  
Climate and weather, which are mainly caused by the air around us, greatly influence the lives of animals and plants. Climate can strongly shape the appearance of landscapes. For example, warm and wet conditions all year round allow tropical jungles to grow, which are full of many different species. In contrast, cold and windy areas can only support a few types of living things. The daily weather patterns that create the climate are caused by large air masses rising and mixing, as the atmosphere is always moving. Some of this movement happens because the layer of gases is on a spinning planet. Since air is light, it does not move at the same speed as the Earth and tends to lag behind. However, a more important cause of air movement is the sun.

Build Your Own Bamboo Bike at the UK's First Workshop**
Join a course at the Bamboo Bike Club, led by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, where you can create your own custom bike frame and enjoy a fun weekend of bike-building. It’s Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London, and the Bamboo Bike Club is busy with activity. This is the only place in Britain where you can learn to build bikes from bamboo.
Bamboo is becoming a popular material for bike construction. Companies like Calfee Design from California and Bamboo Bikes from Yorkshire have been making bamboo bikes since 1894. However, many cyclists find these bikes expensive, with ready-made frames costing around $2,995 or £1,868. This high price motivated James and Ian to spend years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to create a bamboo bike business that is affordable for regular cyclists. They wanted to share the joy of making something unique and sustainable, not just sell bike frames.
Now, the Bamboo Bike Club offers monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame at a reasonable price. On the first day of the course, James and Ian teach participants how to choose strong bamboo and create strong joints. They guide everyone through the process of assembling the bike frame, which includes a front triangle made of thick bamboo and thinner parts for the seat and chain. They also use metal tubes for the handlebars and other parts that need extra strength.
James and Ian are very supportive, helping participants with their work and ensuring everything is done correctly. Many people in the course are engineers, but Ian assures everyone that it’s okay to make mistakes. If you mess up, you can just try again with a new piece of bamboo. Each piece has been checked for quality, so you can choose how your bike will look, whether plain bamboo, black, or mottled.
On Sunday, the focus is on building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the frame. Participants wrap the joints with hemp bindings and glue them with epoxy resin to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and personal touches. James and Ian claim that their bamboo bikes are just as strong as metal ones. Ian has been riding his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months without breaking it.
While bamboo bikes may not look as polished as professional metal frames, they are unique. James and Ian believe that the individuality of each bike is important. Personally, I think bamboo bikes are best for relaxed rides rather than racing. I choose a 'Classic English' frame for a comfortable ride. When I try James's bike, I find it light and smooth, thanks to bamboo's ability to absorb vibrations.
James says that the real joy of these workshops comes when you ride the bike. They are light and fun to ride. And the best part? The price is less than £500.

**Autobiographies**  
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an unspoken agreement that they will tell the truth. However, this agreement is often not fully kept. Writers may leave out things they feel are too shameful or not important enough. Sometimes, they might invent stories that express their truth better than just sticking to the facts. An autobiographer might call their book an autobiography just to make readers believe they are reading true events, even if the story is mostly fiction. This can happen without any intention to deceive.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**  
Experts say that detective stories became popular because they reflect the conflicts of society in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In these stories, crime symbolizes human desires like greed or lust, and solving the crime helps restore order in society. However, in Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same person. The detective understands the criminal, and they share a strange connection. The detective is seen as too honest by criminals and too shady by the law. His job is complicated by his feelings of guilt and his desire for justice.
