**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not developed many differences. Genetically, we are still more than 98% similar to chimps. This means that the things that make us different from animals are very recent. Our biological history suggests that our ability to create art and other unique human traits come from just a small part of our genes. This is a big responsibility for a few genes.
Recent studies of animal behavior show that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language, with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings suggest that there are not many absolute differences between humans and animals, except for art.
If human art comes from a special genetic ability, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art may have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. The first clear evidence of human art appears around 35,000 years ago with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
If we believe that our recent artistic creativity makes us different, we need to consider how our art is different from that of animals. Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it is created for beauty, and it is learned rather than instinctive.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art communicates ideas or feelings, this is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong has clear purposes, like defending territory or attracting a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. By this standard, human art does seem different.
The second claim is that human art is motivated by a desire for beauty. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during the breeding season, suggesting they do not sing just for pleasure. Again, this makes human art seem unique.
The third claim is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from those in Paris. However, these differences are not in the singers' genes. People from different cultures can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' songs, even if they have never heard them before.
The role of learning in human art is also clear because our art styles change quickly. For example, geese have made the same sounds for 2,000 years, but human art evolves rapidly. Even casual museum visitors can tell that a painting from the twentieth century is newer than the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify when and who painted a work, but they might confuse two mid-twentieth-century artists named Congo and Betsy. In reality, these artists were chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 paintings in one day and became upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show of their paintings in 1957 in London, and many of their works sold, which is something many human artists cannot achieve.
These paintings by chimpanzees blur the lines between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the ape paintings were not created for practical purposes; they were made for the satisfaction of the painter. You might argue that human art is different because most human artists intend to communicate with others, while the apes did not care about sharing their paintings. However, this argument is not very strong, as some famous human art was also created for personal satisfaction.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the story. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to be about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes focused on distant horizons. Today, such characters are rare in fiction and in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's great adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert, which means "once entered, you never come out." Local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while at home with his family. His team included four Britons (one was a medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have endangered everyone’s lives and the success of the expedition.
This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's harshest deserts, and Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who I was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t come back since nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was surprisingly good to us."
Anyone reading his incredible story will wonder why he used the word "kind." The team faced many hardships: sickness, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn’t experience the desert's famous sandstorms, and we never faced the freezing cold that could have stopped us completely. That doesn’t mean we didn’t face challenges all the time. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us."
"What pushed me on more than anything was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn’t allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."
If it was tough at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you’re not going to give up. You’ve endured so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was fit, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."
Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How aware was he of how hard it must have been for them? "Inside me, there’s someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to complete that journey. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I’ve done. Yet, when I think of my life’s achievements, I think of my family and the happiness we share — by that measure, the desert does not compare."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge — for the open spaces — the excitement of it all. We were motivated by a sense of purpose. I find it hard now to fit into the sameness of modern life."

Life was getting out of control for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us amazing devices that make life easier and save us time. However, Susan believes that we have been tricked into thinking that technology is the best way to live. 
She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which cost her a lot of money to fix. This made her question whether we really need all these gadgets. Little by little, she has stopped using some household technology as it breaks down. She wonders what kind of "time" technology really gives us. Does it just allow us to do more things that require even more gadgets? 
When her word processor started making strange noises, she decided to leave it outside, where it now sits quietly. She enjoys taking her time with her sewing instead of being tied to a noisy machine. Although she appreciates some gadgets, like her washing machine, she has found joy in living without others. For example, after feeling that they watched too much television, she returned their rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change helped them spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying other hobbies.
One of her hobbies is sewing, and she no longer uses her old sewing machine, which has become a table for plants. Instead, she sews by hand. Many people think they cannot live without their gadgets, but Susan believes that life can be better without them. She feels sorry for those who had to do hard work without machines. 
Computers make our lives easier, but Susan finds that sewing by hand is enjoyable and relaxing. She can listen to the radio or talk with family while she sews. If the task is simple, she can even watch her favorite TV shows while doing something useful. She now enjoys sitting by the fire with a cup of tea while sewing. 
At first, she thought it was terrible for women to spend so much time sewing by hand, but now she sees it as a calming and satisfying activity. She finds that things get done quickly, and she can take her time. She also enjoys washing the dishes and daydreaming while doing it. 
Now, Susan looks around her house and wonders if they really need things like a freezer, a microwave, or an electric lawnmower. She thinks they could save a lot of money by living without electric lights too!

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who creates beautifully crafted furniture. Joanna Watt meets him in his workshop, which is located under a railway arch in East London. When I arrive, he greets me quickly with a handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It is not clear if he is always in a hurry or if he is just shy. Looking around the workshop, I see that Hurst is very busy. There are many pieces of furniture and wooden planks in different natural colors. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has a great reputation. He has many orders lined up for months, even though he does not advertise himself. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the right person to contact.
Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes high-quality furniture with simple designs is more difficult. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people just call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed by the quality of modern furniture. He criticizes mass-produced furniture and craftsmen who make low-quality pieces. Hurst's desire for perfection is a big part of his success, along with his talent. He is confident in his skills and says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." Near the end of our interview, he becomes more modest and says he learned his craft by asking questions and observing.
Most of Hurst's work comes from private clients. He used to work for companies, but he found that unfulfilling. Some clients come back to him for more work, and he enjoys doing their entire house. However, he admits that not all client relationships are easy. He finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want until it is too late. He prefers clients who are clear about their needs.
Although Hurst is proud of his work, he also respects other craftsmen. He says, "There are people far better than me. I can admire other people." He did not train at Parnham, a well-known furniture design college. He is critical of craftsmen who take too long to make one piece and of students who try to make their work fashionable. He believes that furniture should be practical and useful, not just a statement.
Hurst is confident and straightforward, but he is not pretentious. As I leave, he reminds me, "After all, I am only making furniture."

**Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.
The first and most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It suggests that while we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and help us feel better.
The second theory focuses on learning. It claims that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. According to this theory, without sleep, we would not be able to learn effectively.
The third theory is about energy. It says that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day. 
These theories show that sleep plays an important role in our lives, but the exact reasons are still being studied.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted rules of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and strange habits. For example, someone might love entering newspaper competitions, collect beer mats, or write angry letters to the press about various topics. Eccentricity shows our individuality.
Inside us, there is often a struggle between two forces: individualism and conformity. Individualism is the desire to be unique, while conformity is the desire to fit in with others. Most people want to be accepted and liked, which makes conformity stronger than the desire to stand out. 
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs and hold meetings to share their interests, which others might see as strange. Being part of a group can be comforting. Many of us feel a tension between wanting to fit in and wanting to be different. Even when we follow the crowd, we may feel the need to show our individuality. For example, someone might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as you find me."
At any time, we can choose to express our individuality. Many successful people have done this. Bob Dylan, an American singer, once said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing, pursue it without giving up. This may confuse others." However, this strong expression of individuality is not the same as eccentricity, especially at first. 
If a pop singer wears strange clothes just to get attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become a part of who they are, then they can be considered eccentric. The key to eccentricity is that it is natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are.
True eccentrics are not focused on what others think. They act according to who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are aware of society and often react to it. Some want to impress others, while others want to escape from society. In contrast, eccentrics live their lives without worrying about what others think.

**Natural Books**
We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the chance to meet many important figures in this field. One of the most significant is Barbara Ward, a small but strong woman. She has been at the center of environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own powerful ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand these complex topics. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." However, I believe her most important book is "The Home of Man." Although its title sounds old-fashioned, it focuses on the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It is a passionate call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none compare to it.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their droppings in the sun. This book wonderfully explains the interesting world of animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, if you watch a gull colony, you will see that their chaotic activity is actually a well-organized social structure. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a respected behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His collaboration with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's simple yet effective paintings show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm. This is the work of a true naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation, but it also deepened my love for the natural world. I was studying animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, opening this book made my world brighter. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and nature—a small example of a world worth saving. Some people say humans are the worst because of the harm we have caused to other species. However, I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living beings as a family, connected and inseparable. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library shortly after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially to the 48 colorful bird illustrations by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. But "The Shell Bird Book" offered much more. Along with the beautiful illustrations, it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. The wide range of information and exciting images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. The book showed me that my emotional and creative connection to nature is just as important as a scientific one. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new possibilities for myself.

**Do Reviews Sell Books?**
We asked five important British publishers about how book reviews affect a book's success. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. A study showed that many people said they bought a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers often think that even bad reviews can help sales because they get people interested. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinions about a book since they are often the first to read it.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews today are better and more varied than they were 40 years ago, but many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews because they are a cost-effective way to promote a book and its author. A good review from a trusted source can really boost sales, especially if there are several positive reviews.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing. Many of the books we publish are not by famous authors, so we rely on reviews from literary editors. Good reviews are often more valuable than ads because they show that the review is not influenced by money. Publishers often say they care more about the size of the review than its content. Good reviews can help launch a book and a writer's career, but they need support from other factors like recommendations and marketing.
**Publisher D**  
The relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain is complicated. In the United States, a single review from the New York Times can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops often do not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a talented writer. Interestingly, some poorly reviewed books can still sell very well. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on the subject than on the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews, but do they really sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it did not sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. The name of the reviewer can matter. Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people would pay attention. Today, an unexpected reviewer or a clever review can also encourage people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**
The craft of making weathervanes is very old, dating back to ancient Egypt. Today, this skill is still practiced in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who makes weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. "This way, I can make a special item just for them," he says. Many of his customers are women looking for gifts for their husbands. They want something unique that reflects the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's work is different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made was not a cockerel, but a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. "I realized that there are endless possibilities for designs," he explains. Graham decided to focus on making weathervanes. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to change their roles—she went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to care for their children and grow his business. This was five years ago, and he has no regrets about this change. "My previous job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic," he says. "I really enjoy designing."
Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval on the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs available because they are still popular. "People like handmade items," Graham says. "They appreciate having something a little different."
Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love the uniqueness, and I feel satisfied when a simple shape becomes something almost lifelike," he explains. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction." He adds that more people are moving to the countryside and want to add a special touch to their homes, which has helped crafts like his.
Graham is now busier than ever, sending weathervanes to customers around the world. He has noticed a lot of interest from buyers in America and Denmark. "The price depends on how detailed the design is," he explains. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Beginner Takes All**
Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans made him a lot of money. He shares his story about his inspiration and success.
At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was having a tough time. A film project he had been working on, called *Life and Limb*, fell apart suddenly. He was worried because it had been two years since he had earned any money, and he was in debt to his bank. A sensible person in his situation would have found a job, maybe returning to television. But instead, he made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching for his first novel.
Although he acted on impulse, the idea for his story had been in his mind for a while. He had met a farrier (a person who shoes horses) while visiting a friend in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive. The owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These special people were called "horse whisperers." This story inspired Evans.
He started to research horse whisperers, thinking about writing a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. However, after the failure of *Life and Limb*, he decided to write the story as a book. During the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He later said, "It was a strange time. I was watching people, but I felt alone and worried about my life. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and unsure how to support my family."
By the end of August, after returning home, he had written the first half of the book. He was still worried about money and needed to know if he should continue. He showed the manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked for an estimate, he suggested Evans might get $30,000 as an advance for the book. Evans thought about how much he needed to pay off some of his debts, and $30,000 was not enough. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had at least two months of work left. He was also told to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.
In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel and the summary to seven UK publishers just before they went to the Frankfurt Book Fair. Soon, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Evans was shocked and asked, "What?" The agent replied, "It's okay, I feel something good is happening."
What happened next is now famous in publishing. Within a week of competitive bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Evans and his team were amazed. They had not even sent the manuscript to New York, and they still do not know how it got there. They also did not send it to Hollywood, but soon major film studios were interested in it. Evans's UK agent worked with an American agent, who called to say, "I think we can get $3 million for it." They all laughed in disbelief.
That October night, Evans sat in his study while four famous filmmakers called him one after another, asking to pay $3 million for his unfinished novel. He shared this story while we drank coffee on his porch overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been like a fairy tale," he said. "I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very hard, and I don’t want to become just an employee of these people who have paid me so much. I would hate to write a draft and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but we’ll hire someone else now.'"
He wanted to stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was unsure if he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

**Young Masters**
Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to return to chess. Chess is now more of a young person's game. After being away from the game for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in great shape. Spassky is even older. 
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new level of professionalism in the game. Now, winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high. Players use a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time; if they don’t, they lose the game. Nowadays, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks. This increased pressure favors younger players. Over the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30.
The way chess is played has also changed. Much of modern chess preparation happens off the board. Players must prepare seriously before matches, especially because computers have changed the game. A small computer can store one million chess games and provide quick access to many games of an opponent. In recent matches, players have used large teams to analyze each other’s strategies. The opening moves of a game are studied in great detail, and being well-prepared can be crucial.
Today, there are more top players than ever before, and many grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Success in chess requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. A moment of distraction can lead to losing the game. The chess clock adds to the stress, especially during the final moments when players have only seconds to make their moves. In these intense moments, players must act quickly and efficiently, similar to athletes.
At the highest level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess masters must be ready for the next challenge every day. Most chess tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games played daily, and there are competitions throughout the year. World championship matches can be even more demanding. For example, the 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about 10 kg during the match.
Can Bobby Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his decision to leave the chess world after 1972 seem strange. However, it also made him a legend. If he has returned for the money, he is in a good position, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones interviews some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are on their way to success.
**A** Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Nick is very talented, but what is surprising is that he had never been to a play or read one before writing *Peaches*. **B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even in Bristol, he was practicing his comedy in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor; I was always more interested in comedy. "But then I decided I wanted to take it seriously because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for the praise to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. **D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. "The record company's idea of good sales is very different from mine," he says. "They want a big hit, but I just want two people to buy it and be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel tired. I was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. **E** Poet and author Stephen Richards is 27 years old and has won many awards and honors, more than most people twice his age. "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but lost interest in education later. "I decided not to go to university, but I became bored stuffing envelopes at a theater and realized I should go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. With his poetry receiving much praise, moving into novels is a brave step. "My poetry has a structure, and there's less chance of making big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more words that could be bad. My main goal is to avoid just producing work without caring about its quality."

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four academic writers discuss international volunteer work.
A. It is difficult to say that volunteer tourists make a big difference in development. While they can help build homes or schools, they usually pay a lot of money to participate in these projects. This money could be better used if donated directly to local communities, as it could pay for more labor than one volunteer can provide. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often lack the necessary skills or experience. Many studies question whether these volunteers are truly motivated by a desire to help others or if they are more interested in gaining experience that will help their careers. However, these projects can help develop people who may act ethically in their future careers.
B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, and increased participation in global issues through civic organizations. It can also help build international social networks among everyday people. In this way, the overall benefits can be greater than the individual contributions, helping both volunteers and local communities. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals, it may only benefit them and not the communities that need help.
C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that serves the interests of wealthy Westerners rather than the communities they aim to help. On the other hand, it can also provide valuable technical assistance for development. When done well, international volunteering can benefit both volunteers and the organizations they work with, while also allowing for the sharing of skills and cultural experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness about issues like poverty and injustice.
D. Volunteer tourism fits well with the growing trend of helping others. These small efforts to "make a difference" can seem positive, especially in a time when people are skeptical of big government and businesses. However, this approach can ignore the need for democratic government and reduce development to individual acts of charity, which may not truly change the situations of poor communities. While volunteering can be a good thing, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can lead to misunderstandings about real development issues. The focus on volunteer tourism can distract from the serious global inequalities and poverty faced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports
Many of us listen to the radio in the morning, and most of us need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? A group that included myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges tested five clock radios that are currently available.
One model has a 'dual alarm function', which I thought meant you could wake up to a buzzer, snooze for a bit, and then get up. However, the instruction booklet says this function is for setting two different wake-up times: one for weekdays and one for weekends. But who really lives like that? This model costs about the same as another one we tested, but it has a cassette player, which is a nice feature. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up to music instead of news. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but the size is a problem; it is as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges mentioned that he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also said he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.
This model was voted the best overall. Paul Bridges said he was 'in love with it', even though the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can easily tap it without opening your eyes. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which caused problems when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if the power goes out, which we all liked. However, we found it difficult to set up, but once we did, we felt pretty good about it.
Tom Granger thought this model, which has a built-in lamp, was 'very tacky'. He had to pull the light out of its socket to make it work, which made him question the quality of the whole thing. He read the instruction booklet twice before he could get it to work because the clock kept changing from 12:00 to 02:00. The light was hard to position; it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea funny but agreed that the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine and made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. It is aimed at young people, with its bright colors and fun design, which appealed to both Tom Granger and me. Tom said, 'I would choose this one because it stands out more than the others.' 
The traditional controls made it the only model we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin; the manual says, 'the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time.' Paul Bridges laughed at this idea, saying the model was 'very tricky' and 'completely useless'. 
The simplest and cheapest model we tested was liked by Tom Granger because it was 'very standard and took up little space', and it has old-fashioned dial tuning. He said, 'It's easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you’re never sure if you pressed the buttons correctly, so you can’t be confident it will work.' He agreed that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**
A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. All types of hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are attacked, which makes their spines point outwards. This is a good way to protect themselves, but it depends on how many spines they have. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to their environment and have fewer spines, so they are more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up.
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. In good conditions, some hedgehogs will stay awake all year.

Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the articles focus on the men’s events, and only 10% mention the women’s. The prize money is also not as good. Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he could easily recognize Picasso, who was having lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and was lucky to have my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.
Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others to work. So, I was very surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would not have had the courage to go over and ask for his signature. I was nervous when I introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, but to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added some lively lines below. Picasso's art often reflected real things, so those lines might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.
I thanked him and started a shy conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was not great either, an American woman at the table helped us communicate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak freely. Still, I managed to tell Picasso how much I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. But he noticed that Picasso was still having lunch and said, "Is that all? Why don’t you go back and take advantage of this chance? He probably wouldn’t mind if you drew his portrait."
With my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I thought it was better not to ask if I could draw him, as he might say no and ruin the moment. So, I just stood by the table, set my pad against a screen, took out a crayon, and started to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled playfully and made it hard for me to draw. He acted out funny expressions, rolling his eyes and sticking out his tongue, like a clown. I felt like giving up, but his playful spirit challenged me to keep going. 
Eventually, Picasso relaxed and let me study him without distractions. I noticed how strong and alert he looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were full of life. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed a bit distant and alone. He let his friends talk while he quietly focused on his own thoughts.
When the American lady told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketch, he nodded approvingly. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with a single lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.
I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American lady explained that he said I already had his signature. So, he had some limits to his generosity! Still, I feel very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It meant a lot to me.

**Talking Shop**
Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? This text explains some of the tricks that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.
**A. The Image of Freshness**  
Supermarkets know that customers really like fresh food. To create this feeling, they often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that fills the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are chosen because they remind people of fresh produce. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is not fresh.
**B. Displaying to Advantage**  
The way products are placed in a store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas of the store customers visit the most. They put high-profit items in these areas. Products at eye level are especially popular with manufacturers. Special bins with discounts attract bargain hunters. Another strategy is to place related items together, like putting salad dressings near ice cream or burgers.
**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, customers have to walk past more expensive items to get to them. Chain stores also place popular products away from the entrance, hoping that loyal customers will search for them and see other tempting products along the way.
**D. Less Sells More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from the idea of selling many items cheaply. Instead, they create a boutique feel by showing fewer items, making them seem exclusive. Their success comes from good store design as well as stylish clothing.
**E. Tempting Totals**  
Food shoppers often pay more attention to the total cost of their shopping than to the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with more expensive items to attract customers. They sometimes sell certain staples at a loss to bring people in, a strategy known as "loss leaders." They also get low prices by buying in large amounts or by promoting products prominently.
**F. The All-Important Price Tag**  
Customers in chain stores tend to buy fewer items and notice prices more. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.
**G. Lighting to Effect**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores pay attention to lighting. Chain stores try to use lighting that looks like natural light so customers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh foods look more appealing.
**H. Walk This Way**  
Many chain stores use different types of flooring to guide customers. One pattern shows the paths through the store, while another marks sales areas. This strategy, called the "Yellow Brick Road," encourages shoppers to follow certain routes. For example, Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths to lead customers to more inviting carpet in sales areas.
**I. In-Store Promotion**  
As you enter a supermarket, you might see large, colorful pictures of delicious food, which can make you hungry if you haven't eaten. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that show ads for products while you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and can increase sales significantly.

Sea, Ice & Rock**
Chris Bonnington, 58, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 
Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin to ask for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sail. I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first time on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. 
When we reached a steep drop, I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn’t, so I showed him how to do it. After I finished, Robin politely asked if he could go down the way he used ropes on his boat. He was used to using his arms, but I wanted him to use his legs. I was not very happy about it, but he managed to lower himself down safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I built a strong friendship. His idea to combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural next step after our voyage to Skye.
Robin impressed me as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked for everyone’s opinion first. Most of the time, people were too afraid to give him advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. To be honest, I found sailing difficult and boring. The moments of crisis were easy to handle because of the excitement, but spending days in the middle of the sea was hard for me. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. Robin, on the other hand, is a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or repairing the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless.
The crew was also very close together: six people on a 32-foot yacht that was meant for four. When you are on a mountain expedition, you can get away from each other. When we reached Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times when if Robin had fallen, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to be careful about that. I also underestimated how hard climbing the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 
The first time we tried to reach the top, we were climbing for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin worked very hard, but he completely trusted me and just followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted it. I knew that Robin was worried about the boat: whether it would get through the ice and if it was still okay. Still, he wanted to try climbing the mountain again.
The only time we had a problem in our relationship was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns to keep watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me because he thought he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt that he didn’t trust me, which made me feel insecure, and I told him so. Robin quickly reassured me that I was misunderstanding the situation. While we enjoyed the trip to Skye, we didn’t really get to know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**
Apples have been part of human life for a very long time, with many different types in various colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this important part of our heritage.
**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples since ancient times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes by lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, early humans even stored dried apple halves for the winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and not very tasty, which were known in Ancient Britain as "windings." They were very different from the apples we eat today.
**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans, and this knowledge was brought to Britain. The Romans introduced some apple varieties, but many did not grow well in the British climate. After the Norman Conquest, new apple varieties became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new types of apples, which are the ancestors of many Western apples today.
**Medieval Apples (1200)**  
In the thirteenth century, several apple types became common in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, known for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a popular cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century. However, due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, apple production decreased, and more apples were imported. This changed in the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many new apple varieties, including the famous Pippins, and started the first modern orchard in Kent.
**Settlers and Apples (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers who went to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought apples to Australia, and Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa. The Pilgrim Fathers on the Mayflower also carried apples to America. In North America, the famous apple planter was John Chapman, known as "Johnny Appleseed." Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans saw him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees and unique clothing led to many stories about him.
**Modern Apples (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt in Iowa found a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named this apple "Hawkey." When he showed it at a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, this apple was sold as "Delicious" and became one of the most popular apples worldwide.
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was the daughter of convicts and worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales. Known as "Granny Smith," she took care of her family's farm. In 1868, she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit and transplanted it. Soon, she harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. She remarked that it was like God to make something useful from what we consider rubbish, referring to both the apple and her own background.
**The Problem of Uniformity (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, from India to Africa. However, most apples come from only a few varieties, chosen for their appearance or how well they travel, rather than their taste. This lack of variety is a problem, as it reduces the diversity of apples. While some amateur gardeners in the UK have kept old apple varieties alive, the US has lost many apple types from a century ago. Fortunately, consumers are starting to want more variety. It is important that we all work to protect the diversity of apples and other foods for everyone's benefit.
